awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of technology that will provide access to clean water. This project will generate knowledge to develop efficient, cost-effective and sustainable per- and polyfluoroalkyl substance treatment technologies, help the water industry and industry dischargers, prepare our society for water sustainability, and ultimately protect public health. The customers for the technologies include the industrial wastewater dischargers, hazardous waste site managers, municipal water districts, private water companies, chemical manufacturing industries, and government agencies. This project will enhance US technological competitiveness in the water sector by accelerating new knowledge transfer.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a vacuum ultraviolet light-driven photochemical technology for treatment of per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances. This technology is a clean and energy-efficient medium that directly photolyzes water to a pool of energetic radicals. The traditional application of this system for per- and polyfluoroalkyl substance treatment is limited by an unreactive environment (i.e., simultaneous generation of oxidative and reductive radicals) and low quantum yield of radicals. This project will develop an innovative system that overcomes the deficiencies, and elucidate the unique mechanism for generation, propagation, and manipulation of reactive radicals for a complete destruction of per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA AT RIVERSIDE

por.por_cntn:
This project conducted an extensive customer discovery to promote the commercialization of a vacuum ultraviolet light-driven photochemical technology for treatment of per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS). Tunable Vacuum-Ultraviolet Irradiation Systems with Highly Polarized Redox Environment for Treatment of Per- and Polyfluoroalkyl Substances). VUV light is a clean and energy-efficient medium that directly photolyzes water to a pool of energetic radicals. This project developed scale-up and commercialization strategies to develop an innovative VUV system that overcomes the deficiencies, and elucidate the unique mechanism for generation, propagation, and manipulation of reactive radicals in VUV systems for a complete destruction of PFAS. The project team attended the Spring 2023 I-Corp cohort and conduct an extensive customer discovery via virtual and in-person interviews on PFAS treatment technologies, and understood the ecosystem for the technology commercialization. The IP-protected technology addresses global contamination issues of PFAS in water resources through their efficient destruction and will ensure safe drinking water supplies. The proposed technology promises to be highly efficient in destroying PFAS, uses low cost components and will likely supplant several current technologies which are often used sequentially to achieve purity standards. It can increase the sustainability and economic feasibility of future water treatment processes. This research topic is timely and important. It commits to advance commercialization development on how emerging energetic media interact with persistent PFAS in aquatic environment. It will also contribute to addressing the limitations of PFAS transformation reactions and developing feasible and transformative technologies for treatment of PFAS-impacted waste streams. The research goal fits in one of the National Academy of Engineering’s Grand Challenges – provide access to clean water. This project generated transformative knowledge to commercialize efficient, cost-effective and sustainable PFAS treatment technologies, help the water industry and industry dischargers, prepare our society for water sustainability, and ultimately protect public health. The customers for the technologies include the industrial wastewater dischargers, hazardous waste site managers, municipal water districts, private water companies, PFAS chemical manufacturing industries, and government agencies. This project enhances US technological competitiveness in the water sector by accelerating new knowledge transfer.

 


Last Modified: 04/20/2025
Modified by: Haizhou Liu
